etymology.description: 入(入) (rù, "enter") + 玉(玉) (yù, "jade") = a whole piece of jade; pure jade -> complete
etymology.interpretation: 全(全) (quán, "complete") combines 入(入) (rù, "enter") and 玉(玉) (yù, "jade") to symbolize a complete or unblemished piece of jade, reflecting purity and wholeness.

examples.chinese: 他的家全都整洁有序(他的家全都整潔有序)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de jiā quán dōu zhěngjié yǒuxù.
examples.english: His whole house is neat and orderly.

examples.chinese: 他全班都参加了比赛(他全班都參加了比賽)。
examples.pinyin: Tā quán bān dōu cānjiāle bǐsài.
examples.english: His entire class participated in the contest.
